document.title: Family Life Education Board of Education Guidelines and Standards of Learning for Virginia Public Schools

879C454FED5E424FB1B7629181311DBD.description:
Students will learn how to identify when they are in an unsafe
environment. Students learn their full names, addresses, telephone numbers, and how to
find reliable help if lost in a mall or other public place.

63DAFFE283A041A285939026CC5F7B9F.description: The student will find help safely.

C0C1CB7DD08740958791EFAEAE97227D.description:
Descriptive words are used to help the child identify pleasant and
unpleasant feelings. Parents are encouraged to reinforce expressions of feelings at home
and to work with the teacher in a team approach to achieving this, which encourages
good mental health functioning.

1E2744761C1E4B4E9E3F3F70E6D94954.description: The student will identify "feeling good" and "feeling bad."

62DD01B666C94162BEF116405D437B74.description:
This involves learning how to say "no" in a loud voice while
standing up and looking directly at the person. It is important for children to know that
they should tell or report such happenings to a trusted adult such as a parent, teacher,
minister, grandparent, or guardian. In addition, they should understand the need to
continue telling about inappropriate approaches until someone listens and responds.

5EE4795032D544ABBC599495843D618F.description:
The student will demonstrate how to say "no" to inappropriate approaches from
family members, neighbors, strangers, and others.

5E33C6924E8542DD91BEF97056510DB1.description:
Elements of good touches by others are identified as follows: (1)
touching that can be done in front of anyone; (2) touching that is not a secret; (3)
touching that makes the child feel good and not uncomfortable; (4) touching that is done
to provide cleaning or medical care for the child; and (5) touching that is an expression of
affection by a family member. Bad touches by others include the following: (1) touching
on private parts of the body; (2) touching to be kept secret; and (3) touching that could
produce bad feelings.

12CACB4EF4E544CB8370B6A34BBBDCBC.description:
The student will recognize the elements of good (positive or healthy) and bad
(negative or unhealthy) touches by others.

891C7CCE071D4AAD8C786C61E8DB5A8F.description:
It is important for the student to understand that appropriate
expressions of affection are healthy for the individual, the family, and the community.
The student will begin to understand the differences between appropriate and
inappropriate expressions of affection.

968D7AB6C3F944F6926B1FEE87FDF5F8.description:
The student will realize that physical affection can be an expression of friendship, of
celebration, or of a loving family.

FF7974B3B85D47F69A87FB436D899DB7.description:
The focus is on the appropriate words and actions that promote
positive mental health development. Through words and actions which convey care,
protection and guidance, such as touching, listening, hugging, praising, encouraging,
supporting, helping and playing, the child will understand that rules are made for safety,
and protection.

0581BD0534D54A1C8DFB487EC1C33F73.description:
The student will develop an awareness of positive ways in which family members
show love, affection, respect, and appreciation for each other.

ED294FF42377488A84AFC9E4D75D5000.description:
This refers to identifying the adult and child members of the
student's family.

B315AA6AFA924486A3354478D473CCC8.description: The student will identify members of his or her own family.

8AA27510BB9A477BAE54611751B74AD0.description:
The student will recognize that everyone is a member of a family and that families
come in many forms.

D0C421BF9DD0468E9192DA9DC13EAE62.description:
The teacher uses appropriate descriptive language to explain to a
child how his or her behavior affects others positively as well as negatively. The same
descriptive language is used to explain to a child the effects of others' behavior on him or
her. This approach is reinforced by other school personnel and parents are encouraged to
continue such explanations at home. The student is introduced to the concept of privacy,
especially in the use of bathroom facilities. The importance of privacy and boundaries of
self and others is introduced and tools are provided to support the child in respecting the
personal privacy and boundaries of others. In addition, the importance of avoiding gossip
about others' personal or family problems is stressed. Concepts concerning electronic
privacy, such as not sharing your name and address over the Internet, are introduced.

052E8114BD0C4F4E9035ADF59D0F0A5A.description:
The student will become aware of the effects of his or her behavior on others and the
effects of others' behavior on himself or herself.

99CE3E970B844297BA1379E6FC947EE0.description:
Teachers and other adults at school actively listen to and accept
feelings and opinions of the child. A classroom climate that encourages positive mental
health development and protects the child from physical and emotional infringements by
others is provided. The child also learns and practices courtesy and good manners.

54D1EA3667AC48C2A0C392F31A1C1E31.description: The student will experience respect from and for others.

2FEE89D05A44485FA64D3C1138D075AD.description:
These experiences are provided by the teacher through the climate
of the classroom environment and include, but are not limited to, experiencing success in
school, effectively handling routines, experiencing self-acceptance, and acceptance from
others. Parents are encouraged to reinforce these positive experiences and feelings at
home. Emphasis is placed on respect for differences.

50DC92E06BE54B0F8DDF13CC3FE48186.description: The student will experience success and positive feelings about self.
